StorageAbstraction.Name: Windows Azure Blob Service, Paged Blobs
StorageAbstraction.Description: The Blob service provides storage for entities, such as binary files and text files. The REST API for the Blob service exposes two resources: containers and blobs. A container is a set of blobs; every blob must belong to a container. The Blob service defines two types of blobs: Block blobs, which are optimized for streaming. This type of blob is the only blob type available with versions prior to 2009-09-19. Page blobs, which are optimized for random read/write operations and which provide the ability to write to a range of bytes in a blob. Page blobs are available only with version 2009-09-19.

Container.Name: Windows Azure Storage Container
Container.Description: The REST API for the Blob service exposes two resources: containers and blobs. A container is a set of blobs; every blob must belong to a container.

AccessControlList.Name: Windows Azure Access Control Lists
AccessControlList.Description: Every request made against a storage service must be authenticated, unless the request is for a blob or container resource that has been made available for public or signed access.

Object.Name: Windows Azure Page Blob
Object.Description: The Blob service stores text and binary data. The Blob service offers the following three resources: the storage account, containers, and blobs. Within your storage account, containers provide a way to organize sets of blobs. You can store text and binary data in either of two types of blobs: Block blobs, which are optimized for streaming. Page blobs, which are optimized for random read/write operations and which provide the ability to write to a range of bytes in a blob.

Page blobs, which are optimized for random read/write operations and which provide the ability to write to a range of bytes in a blob. Page blobs are available only with version 2009-09-19.

Within your storage account, containers provide a way to organize sets of blobs. You can store text and binary data in either of two types of blobs: Block blobs, which are optimized for streaming. Page blobs, which are optimized for random read/write operations and which provide the ability to write to a range of bytes in a blob.

StorageAbstraction.Name: Windows Azure Blob Service
StorageAbstraction.Description: The Blob service provides storage for entities, such as binary files and text files. The REST API for the Blob service exposes two resources: containers and blobs. A container is a set of blobs; every blob must belong to a container. The Blob service defines two types of blobs: Block blobs, which are optimized for streaming. This type of blob is the only blob type available with versions prior to 2009-09-19. Page blobs, which are optimized for random read/write operations and which provide the ability to write to a range of bytes in a blob. Page blobs are available only with version 2009-09-19.

Container.Name: Windows Azure Storage Container
Container.Description: The REST API for the Blob service exposes two resources: containers and blobs. A container is a set of blobs; every blob must belong to a container.

AccessControlList.Name: Windows Azure Access Control Lists
AccessControlList.Description: Every request made against a storage service must be authenticated, unless the request is for a blob or container resource that has been made available for public or signed access.

Object.Name: Windows Azure Drive
Object.Description: A Windows Azure drive acts as a local NTFS volume that is mounted on the servers file system and that is accessible to code running in a role. The data written to a Windows Azure drive is stored in a page blob defined within the Windows Azure Blob service, and cached on the local file system. Because data written to the drive is stored in a page blob, the data is maintained even if the role instance is recycled. For this reason, a Windows Azure drive can be used to run an application that must maintain state, such as a third-party database application.

AccessControlList.Name: Windows Azure Access Control Lists
AccessControlList.Description: Every request made against a storage service must be authenticated, unless the request is for a blob or container resource that has been made available for public or signed access.

StorageAbstraction.Name: Windows Azure Relational Database Service
StorageAbstraction.Description: With Microsoft SQL Azure, you can create SQL Server databases in the cloud. Using SQL Azure, you can provision and deploy your relational databases and your database solutions to the cloud, without the startup cost, administrative overhead, and physical resource management required by on-premises databases. The paper will examine the internals of the SQL Azure databases, and how they are managed in the Microsoft Data Centers, to provide you high availability and immediate scalability in a familiar SQL Server development environment.

Container.Name: Windows Azure SQL Database
Container.Description: Each SQL Azure server always includes a master database. Up to 149 additional databases can be created for each SQL Azure server. Databases can be created using the SQL Azure Portal or the Transact-SQL CREATE DATABASE command.

Login.Name: Windows Azure SQL Database Logins
Login.Description: In Microsoft SQL Azure Database, when you sign up for the service, the provisioning process creates an SQL Azure server, a database named master, and a login that is the server-level principal of your SQL Azure server. That login is similar to the server-level principal, sa, for an instance of SQL Server on your premises. The SQL Azure server-level principal account always has permission to manage all server-level and database-level security. This topic describes how you can use the server-level principal and other accounts to manage logins and databases in SQL Azure.

StorageAbstraction.Name: Windows Azure Table Service
StorageAbstraction.Description: Tables store data as collections of entities. Entities are similar to rows. An entity has a primary key and a set of properties. A property is a name, typed-value pair, similar to a column. The Table service does not enforce any schema for tables, so two entities in the same table may have different sets of properties. Developers may choose to enforce a schema on the client side. A table may contain any number of entities.

Container.Name: Windows Azure Table
Container.Description: The Table service offers structured storage in the form of tables. The Table service API is a REST API for working with tables and the data that they contain.

AccessControlList.Name: Windows Azure Access Control Lists
AccessControlList.Description: Every request made against a storage service must be authenticated, unless the request is for a blob or container resource that has been made available for public or signed access.

Object.Name: Windows Azure Table Entity
Object.Description: Tables store data as collections of entities. Entities are similar to rows. An entity has a primary key and a set of properties. A property is a name, typed-value pair, similar to a column. The Table service does not enforce any schema for tables, so two entities in the same table may have different sets of properties. Developers may choose to enforce a schema on the client side. A table may contain any number of entities.
